awd_titl_txt: Switched angle spinning NMR probes and stabilized membrane mimetics for oriented biomolecules
awd_abstract_narration:
In this award, the Chemical Measurements and Imaging program of the Chemistry Division supports Dr. Rachel Martin and her students at the University of California at Irvine, to develop novel switched-angle NMR probe and methodology for studying the structure of membrane proteins in their native environment, building on her previous work in this area. In addition to developing experimental and instrumental tools that are optimized for studying oriented liquids, Dr. Martin's group will develop methods for preparing and optimizing model phospholipid membranes based on mixed lipid bicelles, which will facilitate solving the structures of membrane proteins.   These lipid membrane systems are lyotropic liquid crystals, and as such they also are themselves an interesting chemical system for study. 

Membrane proteins are essential for transport of everything that passes in or out of a cell, including nutrients, waste, signaling molecules, and even information. Due to their multi-functionality, these proteins are critical to understanding how cells grow and communicate. In order to understand the function of membrane proteins and find cures for diseases, the structure of the protein in its native environment, that is, embedded in a lipid membrane, is necessary. Despite their importance, there is a paucity of structural information about membrane proteins, because they are difficult to study using traditional techniques. The sophisticated experimental tools that Dr. Martin will develop will help generate the structural information about membrane proteins other scientists need to develop new pharmaceuticals, engineer biomimetic systems, and understand the differences between healthy biological processes and the development of disease states. Dr. Martin is committed to training a diverse and international workforce in issues ranging from scientific literacy to science policy through participation in her research program at UC Irvine.  The educational plan comprises several components, including training of graduate and undergraduate students, as well as outreach to middle school and high school students in grades 6-12 in the framework of UCI's LEAPS program. The goals are increasing interest in science by hosting students in Dr. Martin's lab, and piquing interest in science via hands-on activities and interaction with undergraduate researchers. Dr. Martin's work comprises elements of chemistry, biology, and physics; she will engage students from the undergraduate to the postdoctoral level in her work, and train them in thinking and problem solving across disciplinary boundaries.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: The objective of this project is to develop NMR instrumentation and methods for the investigation of membrane mimetics and membrane proteins.

Switched-angle spinning (SAS) NMR is a multidimensional NMR modality in which the spinning axis is varied during a single experiment, such that an evolution off the magic angle is followed by detection at the magic angle. This results in an isotropic spectrum in the direct dimension correlated to the chemical shift anisotropy or dipolar couplings obtained in the indirect dimension. Therefore, SAS measures the isotropic spectrum that is needed to assign the resonances of different chemical sites, while providing valuable information that would be lost in a simple MAS experiment, all without changing the concentration of any components or the temperature. We are developing biomolecular NMR experiments in which all the anisotropic interactions are recoupled by spinning off the magic angle, and then symmetry-based sequences are used for selective decoupling. This approach takes advantage of the mobility of the sample, making it an asset instead of a liability. Biological SAS will enable  measurement of structural restraints enabling structure determination of membrane proteins under conditions approximating their native milieux.

The SAS probes the Martin group has developed have solved several of the technical limitations limiting the applicability of high-resolution biomolecular SAS. Early prototypes introduced the capacitively coupled circuit connecting the mobile coil to the stationary radiofrequency circuit providing the matching network as well as a purpose-built double saddle coil and a pneumatic switching system for changing the spinning angle. Stable spinning performance is maintained in SAS experiments at rotor speeds up to at least 5 kHz, which is sufficient for our aligned media, since molecular motion partially averages the dipolar couplings and fast spinning can damage the samples. The current generation of biomolecular SAS probes developed as part of this project  includes two different triple-resonance versions. One version uses a new spinning microcoil system that enables the proton circuit to be separately optimized from the 13C and 15N channels, while the other uses nested coaxial capacitors to triple-tune the circuit. We have also demonstrated the use of microcoils (with a volume ≤ 1 μL)  to enhance the sensitivity of small samples in VAS mode, using a microcoil wound around a 0.7 mm capillary and tuned using commercial chip capacitors. 

Careful attention to sample preparation is also important for structural studies of membrane proteins.  Many biological macro- molecules require divalent cations for native structure and / or optimal activity, necessitating an alignment medium that is tolerant of the cations at a variety of concentrations. One limitation on the utility of these membrane systems has been the uncertainty in the effective concentration of free Mg2+ or Ca2+, given that these ions clearly bind the bicelles. Understanding the behavior of the target protein or nucleic acid requires accuate measurement of the free divalent ion concentration under the relevant experimental conditions. An NMR-based method for quantitatively measuring the amount of Mg2+ and Ca2+ bound by biomolecules was developed based on the 31P chemical shift of cytosine diphosphate (CDP), which shifts when a divalent cation is bound. The technique was demonstrated on cholesterol sulfate bicelles, as well as representative nucleic acid and protein samples.

Novel proteins were also discovered as a part of this project, including chitinases, esterase/lipases that synthesize hydrophobic coatings on leaf surfaces, and most notably, the Droserasin 1 PSI, a novel antimicrobial peptide from the carnivorous plant Drosera capensis. The PSI binds to membranes from both bacteria and fungi, disrupting cellular growth and making it potentially useful for fighting pathogens in crop plants. This protein was expressed, purified, and reconsituted in bicelles. NMR measurements have been performed on the PSI bound to fungal lipids, indicating that it is strongly bound to the membrane.  

Broader Impacts: This project has resulted in three completed Ph.Ds as well as training of four undergraduate students and one postdoctoral fellow. It has also supported the Chemical BIology cluster of COSMOS, the California State Summer School for Math and Science in the summers of 2015 and 2016. COSMOS is an intensive, four-week residential program with lectures given by faculty, as well as hands-on laboratory activities. Students attend from high schools all over California, and financial aid is provided for those from economically disadvantaged backgrounds. Each year, 20 students (10 male, 10 female) representing diverse backgrounds and ethnicities participated. Graduate students and undergraduates from the Martin lab played an active role in developing and teaching the laboratory exercises.
